title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0001
text: What is the Strangler Application pattern in microservices refactoring?

options.text: A pattern for incrementally replacing a monolith with microservices
A pattern for merging multiple microservices into one
A pattern for scaling databases horizontally
A pattern for caching API responses

explanation: The Strangler Application pattern incrementally replaces parts of a monolithic system with microservices until the monolith is fully retired.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0002
text: What is the main goal of the Strangler Application pattern?

options.text: To gradually migrate from a monolith to microservices
To rewrite the entire system at once
To reduce the number of services

explanation: The goal is to gradually migrate from a monolithic architecture to microservices without disrupting existing functionality.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0003
text: The Strangler Application pattern is inspired by which natural phenomenon?

options.text: A strangler fig tree growing around a host tree
A coral reef expanding over time
A vine spreading across a wall

explanation: The pattern is inspired by the strangler fig tree, which grows around a host tree and eventually replaces it.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0004
text: What is the first step in applying the Strangler Application pattern?

options.text: Identify a small, independent functionality to extract

explanation: The first step is to identify a small, independent functionality that can be safely extracted into a microservice.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0005
text: Which of the following best describes the migration process in the Strangler pattern?

options.text: Gradually replace monolith components with microservices
Replace the entire monolith in one release
Duplicate all monolith functionality in microservices

explanation: The migration process involves gradually replacing monolith components with microservices until the monolith is obsolete.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0006
text: What role does an API Gateway play in the Strangler pattern?

options.text: It routes requests between the monolith and new microservices

explanation: An API Gateway routes requests to either the monolith or the new microservices during the migration process.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0007
text: Which of the following is a key advantage of the Strangler pattern?

options.text: It allows incremental migration with minimal risk
It eliminates the need for version control

explanation: The Strangler pattern allows incremental migration, reducing risk and enabling continuous delivery.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0008
text: What is a common challenge when using the Strangler pattern?

options.text: Managing data consistency between the monolith and microservices

explanation: A common challenge is maintaining data consistency between the monolith and the new microservices during migration.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0009
text: Which of the following best describes the end state of a successful Strangler migration?

options.text: The monolith is fully replaced by microservices
The monolith and microservices coexist permanently
The monolith is expanded with new features
The microservices are merged back into the monolith

explanation: In a successful Strangler migration, the monolith is fully replaced by microservices and eventually retired.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0010
text: Which of the following is a benefit of using the Strangler pattern for legacy systems?

options.text: It avoids a risky big-bang rewrite
It eliminates the need for version control

explanation: The Strangler pattern avoids the risks of a big-bang rewrite by enabling gradual migration.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0011
text: What is the typical role of a proxy in the Strangler pattern?

options.text: To route traffic between the old and new systems

explanation: A proxy routes traffic between the old monolith and the new microservices during the migration process.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0012
text: Which of the following is a key principle of the Strangler pattern?
explanation: The Strangler pattern is based on the principle of incrementally replacing functionality rather than rewriting everything at once.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0013
text: Which of the following is a risk of not using the Strangler pattern when refactoring a monolith?

options.text: High risk of failure due to big-bang rewrites

explanation: Without the Strangler pattern, a big-bang rewrite can lead to high risk and potential project failure.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0014
text: Which of the following best describes the transition phase in the Strangler pattern?

options.text: Both the monolith and microservices coexist temporarily
The monolith is immediately shut down

explanation: During the transition phase, both the monolith and microservices coexist until the migration is complete.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0015
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for deployment?

options.text: Allows incremental deployment of new services

explanation: The Strangler pattern allows incremental deployment of new services, reducing deployment risk.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0016
text: Which of the following is a common tool used to implement the Strangler pattern?
explanation: An API Gateway or reverse proxy is commonly used to route traffic between the monolith and microservices.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0017
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for risk management?

options.text: Reduces risk by allowing gradual migration

explanation: The Strangler pattern reduces risk by allowing gradual migration and continuous testing.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0018
text: Which of the following is a key indicator that a system is ready for the Strangler pattern?

options.text: The monolith has well-defined modules or boundaries
The monolith has no modular structure
The system is already fully microservices-based
The system has no external interfaces

explanation: A monolith with well-defined modules or boundaries is easier to refactor using the Strangler pattern.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0019
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for testing?

options.text: Allows testing of new services independently
Requires testing the entire system at once

explanation: The Strangler pattern allows independent testing of new services before full integration.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0020
text: Which of the following best describes the final step in the Strangler pattern?

options.text: Decommission the monolith after all functionality is migrated
Expand the monolith with new features
Merge microservices back into the monolith

explanation: The final step is to decommission the monolith once all functionality has been migrated to microservices.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0021
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for business continuity?

options.text: It allows migration without disrupting existing users
It requires complete downtime during migration
It stops all new feature development
It forces a full rewrite before deployment

explanation: The Strangler pattern ensures business continuity by allowing migration without disrupting existing users.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0022
text: Which of the following is a common risk when applying the Strangler pattern?

options.text: Inconsistent data between old and new systems

explanation: Data inconsistency between the monolith and new microservices is a common risk during migration.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0023
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for scalability?

options.text: The monolith must scale as a whole
Scaling requires redeploying the entire system
Scaling is limited to the database

explanation: The Strangler pattern allows new microservices to scale independently, improving performance and flexibility.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0024
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for maintainability?

options.text: Simplifies maintenance by isolating new services

explanation: The Strangler pattern simplifies maintenance by isolating new services from the legacy system.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0025
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for risk reduction?

options.text: Reduces risk by allowing gradual migration

explanation: The Strangler pattern reduces risk by allowing gradual migration and continuous testing.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0026
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for deployment?

options.text: Allows incremental deployment of new services

explanation: The Strangler pattern allows incremental deployment of new services, reducing deployment risk.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0027
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for testing?

options.text: Allows testing of new services independently
Requires testing the entire system at once

explanation: The Strangler pattern allows independent testing of new services before full integration.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0028
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for agility?

options.text: Enables faster delivery of new features

explanation: The Strangler pattern enables faster delivery of new features by allowing incremental changes.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0029
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for fault isolation?

options.text: Failures are contained within new microservices
All services share the same process

explanation: The Strangler pattern improves fault isolation by containing failures within new microservices.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0030
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for flexibility?

options.text: Allows independent evolution of new services

explanation: The Strangler pattern allows independent evolution of new services without affecting the legacy system.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0031
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for resilience?

options.text: Each new service can recover independently

explanation: The Strangler pattern improves resilience by allowing independent recovery of new services.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0032
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for innovation?

options.text: Teams can experiment with new technologies independently
All teams must use the same tools

explanation: The Strangler pattern fosters innovation by allowing teams to experiment independently with new technologies.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0033
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for continuous delivery?
explanation: The Strangler pattern supports continuous delivery by enabling frequent and independent releases.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0034
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for modularity?

options.text: Each new service is modular and focused on a single business function

explanation: The Strangler pattern promotes modularity by designing each new service around a single business function.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0035
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for observability?

options.text: Provides visibility into both old and new systems

explanation: The Strangler pattern improves observability by providing visibility into both old and new systems during migration.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0036
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for alignment?

options.text: Aligns technical architecture with business goals

explanation: The Strangler pattern aligns technical architecture with business goals by enabling gradual modernization.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0037
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for adaptability?

options.text: Allows quick adaptation to business changes

explanation: The Strangler pattern allows quick adaptation to business changes without affecting the entire system.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0038
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for ownership?

options.text: Clear ownership of new services by specific teams

explanation: The Strangler pattern provides clear ownership of new services by specific teams, improving accountability.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0039
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for communication?

options.text: Reduces inter-team communication by defining clear boundaries

explanation: The Strangler pattern reduces inter-team communication by defining clear boundaries between old and new systems.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0040
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for clarity?

options.text: Provides clear separation of old and new functionality

explanation: The Strangler pattern provides clear separation of old and new functionality during migration.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0041
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for reliability?

options.text: Each new service can handle failures independently

explanation: The Strangler pattern improves reliability by allowing independent failure handling for new services.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0042
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for continuous improvement?

options.text: Teams can iterate and improve new services independently

explanation: The Strangler pattern allows teams to iterate and improve new services independently.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0043
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for accountability?

options.text: Each team is accountable for its new services
Accountability is shared across all teams

explanation: The Strangler pattern ensures accountability by assigning responsibility for new services to specific teams.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0044
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for performance optimization?

options.text: Teams can optimize performance for new services independently

explanation: The Strangler pattern allows teams to optimize performance for new services independently.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0045
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for transparency?
explanation: The Strangler pattern improves transparency by providing visibility into migration progress and system state.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0046
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for business alignment?

options.text: Ensures new services align with business priorities

explanation: The Strangler pattern ensures that new services align with business priorities and goals.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0047
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for independence?

options.text: Each new service can operate independently
All services depend on each other
Services require orchestration for every call

explanation: The Strangler pattern allows each new service to operate independently without relying on the monolith.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0048
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for scalability?

options.text: Each new service can scale independently
Scaling requires redeploying the entire system
Scaling is limited to the database

explanation: The Strangler pattern allows independent scaling of new services based on their specific performance needs.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0049
text: Which of the following is a benefit of the Strangler pattern for reliability?

options.text: Each new service can handle failures independently

explanation: The Strangler pattern improves reliability by allowing independent failure handling for new services.

title: MicroservicesRefactoringStranglerApplication - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes the purpose of the Strangler pattern?

options.text: To incrementally replace a monolith with microservices while minimizing risk
To rewrite the entire system at once
To merge microservices into a monolith

explanation: The purpose of the Strangler pattern is to incrementally replace a monolith with microservices while minimizing risk and disruption.
